title: Presbyterian Schools
description:
Presbyterian schools are Christian educational institutions in the Reformed tradition, emphasizing God's sovereignty, biblical authority, and covenant community.

Key characteristics of Presbyterian schools:

• Rooted in Reformed theology and the Westminster Confession
• Strong emphasis on biblical literacy and theological education
• Tradition of rigorous academic excellence
• Covenant community approach to education
• Focus on developing a Christian worldview
• Often feature classical or traditional educational methods

Presbyterian schools may be affiliated with various Presbyterian denominations, including the Presbyterian Church in America (PCA), Presbyterian Church (USA), or other Reformed bodies. Each has somewhat different theological emphases.

The Presbyterian tradition has a strong historical commitment to education, believing that a well-educated mind is essential for understanding Scripture and serving God effectively.

These schools often emphasize critical thinking, logic, and rhetoric alongside biblical instruction.

When considering a Presbyterian school, ask about their specific denominational affiliation, catechism instruction, and approach to Reformed theology.
